Growth orders and ergodicity for absolutely CesÃ ro bounded operators

Luciano Abadias Departamento de MatemÃ¡ticas, Instituto Universitario de MatemÃ¡ticas y Aplicaciones, Universidad de Zaragoza, 50009 Zaragoza, Spain. labadias@unizar.es Â andÂ  Antonio Bonilla Departamento de AnÃ¡lisis MatemÃ¡tico, Universidad de la Laguna, 38271, La Laguna (Tenerife), Spain. abonilla@ull.es
Abstract.

In this paper, we extend the concept of absolutely CesÃ ro boundedness to the fractional case. We construct a weighted shift operator belonging to this class of operators, and we prove that if Tğ‘‡T is an absolutely CesÃ ro bounded operator of order Î±ğ›¼\alpha with 0<Î±â‰¤1,0ğ›¼10<\alpha\leq 1, then â€–Tnâ€–=oâ€‹(nÎ±)normsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›ğ‘œsuperscriptğ‘›ğ›¼\|T^{n}\|=o(n^{\alpha}), generalizing the result obtained for Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1. Moreover, if Î±>1ğ›¼1\alpha>1, then â€–Tnâ€–=Oâ€‹(n)normsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›ğ‘‚ğ‘›\|T^{n}\|=O(n). We apply such results to get stability properties for the CesÃ ro means of bounded operators.

Key words and phrases:
Absolutely CesÃ ro bounded, Kreiss bounded, backward shift operator, ergodicity.

Recall that a bounded linear operator Tğ‘‡T on Xğ‘‹X is called (C,Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼(C,\alpha)-CesÃ ro bounded if the CesÃ ro mean of order Î±ğ›¼\alpha of T,ğ‘‡T, (MTÎ±â€‹(n))nâˆˆâ„•0,subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‡ğ›¼ğ‘›ğ‘›subscriptâ„•0(M_{T}^{\alpha}(n))_{n\in\mathbb{N}_{0}}, is uniformly bounded. The particular cases Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0 and Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1 are well-known, the power boundedness and CesÃ ro boundedness respectively. It is known that (C,Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼(C,\alpha)-CesÃ ro boundedness implies (C,Î²)ğ¶ğ›½(C,\beta)-CesÃ ro boundedness for Î²>Î±â‰¥0,ğ›½ğ›¼0\beta>\alpha\geq 0, however the converse is not true in general: the Assani matrix is CesÃ ro bounded but it is not power bounded. In the case that (MTÎ±â€‹(n))nâˆˆâ„•0subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‡ğ›¼ğ‘›ğ‘›subscriptâ„•0(M_{T}^{\alpha}(n))_{n\in\mathbb{N}_{0}} converges in the strong topology of X,ğ‘‹X, we say that the operator Tğ‘‡T is (C,Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼(C,\alpha)-mean ergodic (for Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1 it said to be mean ergodic). Properties, characterization thorough functional calculus and ergodic results for (C,Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼(C,\alpha)-CesÃ ro bounded operators can be found in [2, 3, 7, 8, 9, 10, 15] and references therein.


Also, there are connections between some boundedness of the CesÃ ro means and the resolvent of T.ğ‘‡T. We recall that the condition

where Cğ¶C is a positive constant. There exist Kreiss bounded operators which are not CesÃ ro bounded, and reciprocally, CesÃ ro boundedness does not imply Kreiss boundedness, see [22]. Also, there are Kreiss bounded operators that they are not uniformly Kreiss bounded, see [17]. Moreover, in finite dimensional Hilbert spaces, Kreiss bounded and power bounded are equivalent classes of operators, see [17].


Growth orders for the CesÃ ro means of any order (especially for the natural powers) of (C,Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼(C,\alpha)-CesÃ ro bounded or Kreiss bounded operators have been studied in a large amount of papers ([1, 9, 15, 19, 22] and references therein). In the following remark, we include some interesting particular cases.

Remark 1.1.

Furthermore, a similar result to the part i) is true for Î±â‰¥1,ğ›¼1\alpha\geq 1, that is, if Tğ‘‡T is (C,Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼(C,\alpha)-CesÃ ro bounded with Î±â‰¥1ğ›¼1\alpha\geq 1 and Ïƒâ€‹(T)âˆ©âˆ‚ğ”»âŠ‚{1},ğœğ‘‡ğ”»1\sigma(T)\cap\partial\mathbb{D}\subset\{1\}, then â€–Tnâ€–=oâ€‹(nÎ±)normsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›ğ‘œsuperscriptğ‘›ğ›¼\|T^{n}\|=o(n^{\alpha}) ([1, Theorem 4.3]). Recently in [12], the authors introduced a new concept about the growth of the CesÃ ro means. An operator Tâˆˆâ„¬â€‹(X)ğ‘‡â„¬ğ‘‹T\in\mathcal{B}(X) is called absolutely CesÃ ro bounded, if there exists C>0ğ¶0C>0 such that

supnâˆˆâ„•01n+1â€‹âˆ‘j=0nâˆ¥Tjâ€‹xâˆ¥â‰¤Câ€‹âˆ¥xâˆ¥,xâˆˆX.formulae-sequencesubscriptsupremumğ‘›subscriptâ„•01ğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğ‘—0ğ‘›delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘—ğ‘¥ğ¶delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘‹\sup_{n\in\mathbb{N}_{0}}\frac{1}{n+1}\sum_{j=0}^{n}\lVert T^{j}x\rVert\leq C\lVert x\rVert,\quad x\in X.

The starting point of the above concept is related to the distributional chaos theory. In [5], some examples of absolutely CesÃ ro bounded are given, as well as its connection with power bounded and Kreiss bounded properties. Also they prove that if Tğ‘‡T is an absolutely CesÃ ro bounded operator, then â€–Tnâ€–=oâ€‹(n).normsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›ğ‘œğ‘›\|T^{n}\|=o(n). In this paper we introduce an extension of the absolutely CesÃ ro boundedness, and our main aim is to construct simple examples, to study the asymptotic behaviour of the orbits, to compare with other mentioned concepts, and to show ergodic results.

Definition 1.1.

Let Î±>0.ğ›¼0\alpha>0. We say that a bounded linear operator Tğ‘‡T on Xğ‘‹X is absolutely (C,Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼(C,\alpha)-CesÃ ro bounded if there exists a constant C>0ğ¶0C>0 such that

supnâˆˆâ„•01kÎ±+1â€‹(n)â€‹âˆ‘j=0nkÎ±â€‹(nâˆ’j)â€‹â€–Tjâ€‹xâ€–â‰¤Câ€‹â€–xâ€–,subscriptsupremumğ‘›subscriptâ„•01superscriptğ‘˜ğ›¼1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘—0ğ‘›superscriptğ‘˜ğ›¼ğ‘›ğ‘—normsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘—ğ‘¥ğ¶normğ‘¥\sup_{n\in\mathbb{N}_{0}}\frac{1}{k^{\alpha+1}(n)}\sum_{j=0}^{n}k^{\alpha}(n-j)\|T^{j}x\|\leq C\|x\|\;,

for all xâˆˆXğ‘¥ğ‘‹x\in X.

For Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1, the above definition is the absolutely CesÃ ro boundedness. In order to clarify to the reader, we show the following sketch:

Power boundedÂ â‡’Â AbsolutelyÂ â€‹(C,Î±)â€‹-CesÃ ro boundedÂ â‡’Power boundedÂ Â AbsolutelyÂ ğ¶ğ›¼-CesÃ ro boundedÂ \text{Power bounded }\Rightarrow\text{ Absolutely }(C,\alpha)\text{-Ces\`{a}ro bounded }
â‡’(C,Î±)â€‹-CesÃ ro boundedÂ â‡’â€–Tnâ€–=Oâ€‹(nÎ±)â‡’absentğ¶ğ›¼-CesÃ ro boundedÂ â‡’normsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›ğ›¼\Rightarrow\ (C,\alpha)\text{-Ces\`{a}ro bounded }\Rightarrow\ \|T^{n}\|=O(n^{\alpha})

Particularly, it follows that all absolutely CesÃ ro bounded operators are uniformly Kreiss bounded, and that every absolutely (C,2)ğ¶2(C,2)-CesÃ ro bounded operator is Kreiss bounded.


The outline of this paper is as follows: In Section 2, for 0<Î±â‰¤1,0ğ›¼10<\alpha\leq 1, we construct a class of weighted backward shift operators (TÎ²)Î²>0subscriptsubscriptğ‘‡ğ›½ğ›½0(T_{\beta})_{\beta>0} on â„“pâ€‹(â„•),superscriptâ„“ğ‘â„•\ell^{p}(\mathbb{N}), for 1â‰¤p<âˆ,1ğ‘1\leq p<\infty, which are mixing absolutely (C,Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼(C,\alpha)-CesÃ ro bounded with â€–Tnâ€–=(n+1)Î²normsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›1ğ›½\|T^{n}\|=(n+1)^{\beta} for 0<Î²<Î±/p0ğ›½ğ›¼ğ‘0<\beta<\alpha/p (Theorem 2.1 and Corollary 2.1), and no (C,Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼(C,\alpha)-CesÃ ro bounded if Î²â‰¥1/pğ›½1ğ‘\beta\geq 1/p (Remark 2.1). In Hilbert spaces, for 0<Î±â‰¤1,0ğ›¼10<\alpha\leq 1, if Tğ‘‡T is an absolutely (C,Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼(C,\alpha)-CesÃ ro bounded operator then â€–Tnâ€–=oâ€‹(nmâ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹{Î±,1/2})normsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›ğ‘œsuperscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›ğ›¼12\|T^{n}\|=o(n^{min\{\alpha,1/2\}}) (Corollary 2.5). In Section 3, we study some ergodic applications. We prove that the absolutely (C,Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼(C,\alpha)-CesÃ ro boundedness in a reflexive Banach space implies (C,Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼(C,\alpha)-mean ergodicity (Corollary 3.1). 2. Examples and growth orders of absolutely CesÃ ro bounded operators

Remark 2.1.

Let 0<Î±â‰¤10ğ›¼10<\alpha\leq 1, 1â‰¤p<âˆ,1ğ‘1\leq p<\infty, Î²>0ğ›½0\beta>0 and Tğ‘‡T be the unilateral weighted backward shift operator on â„“pâ€‹(â„•)superscriptâ„“ğ‘â„•\ell^{p}(\mathbb{N}) defined in Theorem 2.1. Then the operator Tğ‘‡T is absolutely (C,Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼(C,\alpha)-CesÃ ro bounded if Î²<Î±/pğ›½ğ›¼ğ‘\beta<\alpha/p (Theorem 2.1) and no (C,Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼(C,\alpha)-CesÃ ro bounded if Î²â‰¥1/pğ›½1ğ‘\beta\geq 1/p (Proposition 2.1).

From now to the end of the section we focus on studying the growth of the natural powers of absolutely (C,Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼(C,\alpha)-CesÃ ro bounded operators.

3. Ergodic applications for the CesÃ ro means

In this section we study the ergodic behaviour of the CesÃ ro means supposing several assumptions, both the geometry of the Banach space Xğ‘‹X, and spectral and growth conditions on the operator T.ğ‘‡T.

In the first results, the reflexive property plays role. As consequence of Corollary 2.2, Corollary 2.3 and [10, Proposition 3.2], we obtain the following result.

Corollary 3.1.

Let Î±>0ğ›¼0\alpha>0. Every absolutely (C,Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼(C,\alpha)-CesÃ ro bounded operator in a reflexive Banach space is (C,Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼(C,\alpha)-mean ergodic.
